update.description:
PR #571 made `ToString` not print unset values. 
When converting between versions of sdf, the converter may add an element with a required attribute, but the added attribute is not considered "set". When using `ToString` on the parsed object, this attribute will not be printed. Trying to parse the output of `ToString` will fail because there is now a missing value on a required attribute.


For example, when the following snippet gets parsed, it gets upconverted into sdf 1.6.

```
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">
  </world>
</sdf>
```

One element that gets added during this conversion is `<atmosphere>` which has a required attribute `type`. Here's the output of `ToString`:
```
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.6'>
  <world name='default'>
    <gravity>0 0 -9.8</gravity>
    <magnetic_field>6e-06 2.3e-05 -4.2e-05</magnetic_field>
    <atmosphere/>
    <physics>
      <max_step_size>0.001</max_step_size>
      <real_time_factor>1</real_time_factor>
      <real_time_update_rate>1000</real_time_update_rate>
    </physics>
    <scene>
      <ambient>0.4 0.4 0.4 1</ambient>
      <background>0.7 0.7 0.7 1</background>
      <shadows>1</shadows>
    </scene>
  </world>
</sdf>
```
Parsing this in will fail because `<atmosphere>` is missing its `type` attribute.


This PR also ensures that that clones of `sdf::Element` have identical outputs from calling `ToString`.
update.title: Fix ToString on required attributes and cloned elements

pull_request.title: Fix ToString on required attributes and cloned elements

content.raw:
Aye, that’d sound better. Does that imply a redux of the PR? \(And I guess the relevant question is, is it worth the redux, or should we add this in for now?\)

‌
content.html:
Aye, that’d sound better. Does that imply a redux of the PR? (And I guess the relevant question is, is it worth the redux, or should we add this in for now?)

‌

pull_request.title: Fix ToString on required attributes and cloned elements

pullrequest.title: Fix ToString on required attributes and cloned elements

content.raw: Ah, sorry, I had said “set” too abstractly; I understand that it doesn’t set the value in the object, but rather in the XML doc. \(If you do a round-trip, then it would be “set”.\)
content.html: Ah, sorry, I had said “set” too abstractly; I understand that it doesn’t set the value in the object, but rather in the XML doc. (If you do a round-trip, then it would be “set”.)

pull_request.title: Fix ToString on required attributes and cloned elements

pullrequest.title: Fix ToString on required attributes and cloned elements

content.raw: I would also say that serializing an invalid element is a rare use case, possibly only used for testing. I would rather add a different function for that when the need arises.
content.html: I would also say that serializing an invalid element is a rare use case, possibly only used for testing. I would rather add a different function for that when the need arises.

pull_request.title: Fix ToString on required attributes and cloned elements

pullrequest.title: Fix ToString on required attributes and cloned elements

content.raw:
this isn't setting any attributes; it's just printing the values, which will be the default value if the attribute was unset

does that make sense?
content.html:
this isn't setting any attributes; it's just printing the values, which will be the default value if the attribute was unset

does that make sense?

pull_request.title: Fix ToString on required attributes and cloned elements

pullrequest.title: Fix ToString on required attributes and cloned elements

content.raw:
nit It seems a bit odd to carte-blanche set all unset required attributes directly in `ToString()`…

It makes total sense in the case of conversion, but not so much when constructing other elements, in that you can serialize an invalid element…

Is there a way to somehow constrain this to conversion? \(If not, no worries.\)
content.html:
nit It seems a bit odd to carte-blanche set all unset required attributes directly in ToString()…

It makes total sense in the case of conversion, but not so much when constructing other elements, in that you can serialize an invalid element…

Is there a way to somehow constrain this to conversion? (If not, no worries.)

content.raw:
I made a couple small changes:

* d752e2c: fix a whitespace-related codecheck complaint
* 3f33fd3: fix spelling
* 72a16cd: fix a weird error message about sdf version 0.2.3 that was caused by side-effects of one test affecting others
content.html:
I made a couple small changes:

  • d752e2c: fix a whitespace-related codecheck complaint
  • 3f33fd3: fix spelling
  • 72a16cd: fix a weird error message about sdf version 0.2.3 that was caused by side-effects of one test affecting others
